text:
Share Unthinkable tragedy : Cop pulls over car with 13 people packed inside - Yahoo New Zealand A police officer has stopped an 'unthinkable tragedy' when she pulled over a vehicle with 13 people inside - including a baby and eight children without seat belts. SOURCE: NZME 'Unthinkable tragedy': Cop pulls over car with 13 people packed inside 
Constable Sheryll Pearce responded to a call from a member of the public about the safety of unrestrained children in a car on Auckland's Northern Motorway last month. 
But when she got there she was left astounded at the number of children roaming free inside the already packed vehicle. 
According to Pearce, only two adults in the front were wearing seat belts, while three women and eight children, including a baby, were packed into five back seats. 
She told the Herald on Sunday that there could have been an "unthinkable" tragedy if police weren't alerted. 
"When I opened the door, there was just this seething mass of unrestrained humanity. I just could not believe how many bodies were inside," Pearce told the Herald on Sunday. 
"It's unthinkable that adults who have children they love could not care enough about making sure their children were secure. I was appalled." Constable Sheryll Pearce was nearly in tears after the family couldn't understand why she was so upset at the situation. Photo: SNPA/Screengrab 
Pearce revealed one of the women in the car thought it was acceptable to breast-feed her baby and got angry at the Constable, nearly reducing Pearce to tears. 
The family of 13 could have been issued a total of 11 tickets, but Pearce issued just two, instead sending the family to a car shop to buy appropriate child seating. 
She told the Herald on Sunday that education was more important than a hefty fine. 
"I felt their money was better spent getting child restraints than fining them into the ground. I really hope what happened has made a difference to them in the long-term. 
"If their vehicle had been in a crash, there could have been a lot of deaths, or very serious injuries. You're talking about cars travelling about 100km/h." 
Pearce had the family arrange another vehicle before they were allowed to continue their journey. 
National road policing manager Superintendent Steve Greally praised Pearce's handling of the situation, saying her approach ensured the kids were safer and noted that too many infringement notices could have led to no payment and no benefit to the children.
